Nobody is above the law, no newspaper editor, no journalist. Andy Coulson quit on Friday after fresh revelations in recent months over what he knew about phone hacking at the News of the World when he was editor. He quit the post in January 2007 after

on him grew this month when the newspaper suspended his former news editor over hacking claims. Tony Blair 's former spin doctor Alastair Campbell said there was a "greater stench" to the scandal. He said: First, there's the issue of David Cameron and George Osborne 's judgment, then there's the News of the World and what appears to be industrial phone hacking going on systematically. "There's also the issue of the News Corp takeover of BSkyB and the apparent attempts by Jeremy Hunt, the Culture Secretary, to let that go through without proper scrutiny, and finally there's the extraordinary conduct of the police. " Eric Schmidt 's explanation of his role change is seen by many as a nice way of acknowledging what former Google designer Douglas Bowman said when he famously left the Internet giant in 2009: Yes, it's true that a team at Google couldn't decide between two blues, so they're testing 41 shades between each blue to see which one performs better. I had a recent debate over whether a border should be 3, 4 or 5 pixels wide, and was asked to prove my case. I can't operate in an environment like that. I've grown tired of debating such minuscule design decisions. There are more exciting design problems in this world to tackle. What else does the change mean? Check out some deeper concerns here.
